Third-order optical conductivity of an electron fluid

Zhiyuan Sun Department of Physics, University of California San Diego, 9500 Gilman Drive, La Jolla, California 92093, USA ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ D. N. Basov Department of Physics, University of California San Diego, 9500 Gilman Drive, La Jolla, California 92093, USA Department of Physics, Columbia University, 538 West 120th Street, New York, New York 10027 ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ M. M. Fogler Department of Physics, University of California San Diego, 9500 Gilman Drive, La Jolla, California 92093, USA
Abstract

We derive the nonlinear optical conductivity of an isotropic electron fluid at frequencies below the interparticle collision rate. In this regime, governed by hydrodynamics, the conductivity acquires a universal form at any temperature, chemical potential, and spatial dimension. We show that the nonlinear response of the fluid to a uniform field is dominated by the third-order conductivity tensor œÉ(3)superscriptùúé3\sigma^{(3)} whose magnitude and temperature dependence differ qualitatively from those in the conventional kinetic regime of higher frequencies. We obtain explicit formulas for œÉ(3)superscriptùúé3\sigma^{(3)} for Dirac materials such as graphene and Weyl semimetals. We make predictions for the third-harmonic generation, renormalization of the collective-mode spectrum, and the third-order circular magnetic birefringence experiments.

I Introduction

In typical metals and semiconductors electrons experience frequent collisions with impurities and phonons. The combined rate Œìd=Œìd‚Äãi‚Äãs+Œìp‚ÄãhsubscriptŒìùëësubscriptŒìùëëùëñùë†subscriptŒìùëù‚Ñé\Gamma_{d}=\Gamma_{dis}+\Gamma_{ph} of these collisions far exceeds the rate Œìe‚ÄãesubscriptŒìùëíùëí\Gamma_{ee} of electron-electron scattering. However, in several pure materials the opposite case Œìd‚â™Œìe‚Äãemuch-less-thansubscriptŒìùëësubscriptŒìùëíùëí\Gamma_{d}\ll\Gamma_{ee} has recently shown to be possible in a range of temperatures. Under such conditions¬†Gurzhi (1968); Andreev¬†et¬†al. (2011) electrons behave as a fluid that obeys hydrodynamic equations.¬†Landau¬†and¬†Lifshitz (1987) Evidence for the hydrodynamic behavior has been obtained from dc transport experiments with two-dimensional (2D) electron gases in GaAs de¬†Jong¬†and¬†Molenkamp (1995), graphene,¬†Bandurin¬†et¬†al. (2016); Crossno¬†et¬†al. (2016); Krishna Kumar¬†et¬†al. (2017) and a quasi-2D metal PdCoO2subscriptPdCoO2\mathrm{PdCoO_{2}}.¬†Moll¬†et¬†al. (2016) These discoveries stimulated many theoretical studies.¬†M√ºller¬†et¬†al. (2008, 2009); Phan¬†et¬†al. ; Forcella¬†et¬†al. (2014); Briskot¬†et¬†al. (2015); Narozhny¬†et¬†al. (2015); Principi¬†and¬†Vignale (2015a, b); Sun¬†et¬†al. (2016); Lucas¬†et¬†al. (2016); Lucas (2017); Sun¬†et¬†al. ; Guo¬†et¬†al. (2017) The conceptual simplicity of hydrodynamics arises from dealing with only a few degrees of freedom: the local temperature T‚Äã(ùê´,t)ùëáùê´ùë°T(\mathbf{r},t), chemical potential Œº‚Äã(ùê´,t)ùúáùê´ùë°\mu(\mathbf{r},t), and the flow velocity ùêÆ‚Äã(ùê´,t)ùêÆùê´ùë°\mathbf{u}(\mathbf{r},t). The complicated many-body collisions need not be considered explicitly. In our previous paper¬†Sun¬†et¬†al. we used this hydrodynamic formalism to calculate the electrodynamic response of an electron fluid, in particular, its linear and second-order nonlinear optical conductivities. The magnitude and functional form of these quantities in the hydrodynamic regime of frequencies œâ‚â™Œìe‚Äãemuch-less-thanùúîsubscriptŒìùëíùëí\omega\ll\Gamma_{ee} were shown to differ qualitatively from their counterparts in the conventional kinetic regime œâ‚â´Œìe‚Äãemuch-greater-thanùúîsubscriptŒìùëíùëí\omega\gg\Gamma_{ee}. Here we continue this line of investigation by addressing the third-order nonlinearity, which controls, e.g., the third-harmonic generation (Fig.¬†1), the Kerr effect, and four-wave mixing.

One reason why the third-order nonlinearity warrants attention is dictated by the symmetry. In general, the electrodynamic response of a conductor is characterized by the tensors œÉ(n)superscriptùúéùëõ\sigma^{(n)} describing the components of the induced current proportional to the nùëõnth-power of the electric field. (The definition of these tensors is given in Sec.¬†II). Unless the field is very strong, the nonlinear response of a material lacking the inversion symmetry is dominated by the second-order conductivity œÉ(2)superscriptùúé2\sigma^{(2)}. However, in centro-symmetric systems, such as graphene, œÉ(2)superscriptùúé2\sigma^{(2)} must vanish if the electric field is uniform, in which case the third-order conductivity œÉ(3)superscriptùúé3\sigma^{(3)} becomes more important.

As we show below in this paper, the derivation of the nonlinear conductivities is straightforward within a certain model that we call the Dirac fluid. This model is simple yet flexible enough to describe several types of solid-state materials. The model assumes that the quasiparticles of the system behave as Dirac fermions with the energy-momentum dispersion Œµ2‚Äã(ùê©)=m2‚Äãv4+ùê©2‚Äãv2superscriptùúÄ2ùê©superscriptùëö2superscriptùë£4superscriptùê©2superscriptùë£2\varepsilon^{2}(\mathbf{p})=m^{2}v^{4}+\mathbf{p}^{2}v^{2}. The massless case m=0ùëö0m=0 corresponds to electrons in graphene; the massive case m>0ùëö0m>0 is a reasonable approximation for narrow-gap semiconductors. Neglecting fermion-fermion interactions, one can readily compute the equilibrium thermodynamic parameters of this system,¬†M√ºller¬†et¬†al. (2008, 2009); Briskot¬†et¬†al. (2015); Sun¬†et¬†al. (2016, ) such as the pressure P=P‚Äã(Œº,T)ùëÉùëÉùúáùëáP=P(\mu,T) and the energy density nE=nE‚Äã(Œº,T)subscriptùëõùê∏subscriptùëõùê∏ùúáùëán_{E}=n_{E}(\mu,T). The crucial simplification of the Dirac model is that the energy-momentum tensor of the moving fluid can be derived from that of the static one by a Lorentz transformation with vùë£v in lieu of the speed of light cùëêc. [In the noninteracting case, the moving fluid is defined as the Fermi distribution of quasiparticles with the Doppler-shifted energies Œµ‚Äã(ùê©)‚àíùê©ùêÆùúÄùê©ùê©ùêÆ\varepsilon(\mathbf{p})-\mathbf{p}\mathbf{u}.] The Lorentz invariance ensures that the hydrodynamic equations of a Dirac fluid have a simple ‚Äúrelativistic‚Äù form.¬†Landau¬†and¬†Lifshitz (1987); M√ºller¬†et¬†al. (2008, 2009); Briskot¬†et¬†al. (2015); Narozhny¬†et¬†al. (2015); Sun¬†et¬†al. (2016, ) Precisely because v‚â†cùë£ùëêv\neq c, the solid-state systems with real Coulomb interactions are not truly Lorentz-invariant. However, the Dirac fluid should be a reasonable approximation if the Coulomb interactions are not too strong, so that PùëÉP and nEsubscriptùëõùê∏n_{E} are dominated by the kinetic energy. Besides graphene, examples of such Dirac fluids may include the surface states of topological insulators and three-dimensional Dirac/Weyl semimetals.

Note that the hydrodynamics regimes probed by recent dc transport experiments¬†Bandurin¬†et¬†al. (2016); Crossno¬†et¬†al. (2016); Krishna Kumar¬†et¬†al. (2017) is less than 111-THzTHz\mathrm{THz} wide. If one wants to expand it toward higher œâùúî\omega, it is necessary to increase Œìe‚ÄãesubscriptŒìùëíùëí\Gamma_{ee}, which can be done by raising electron temperature TùëáT (Fig.¬†2). This must be done without heavily increasing the electron-phonon scattering rate Œìp‚ÄãhsubscriptŒìùëù‚Ñé\Gamma_{ph}, which is also temperature-dependent. One possible solution¬†Sun¬†et¬†al. is to work with (steady or transient) states where electrons are ‚Äúhot‚Äù but lattice stays ‚Äúcold.‚Äù Such nonequilibrium states can be created by optical pumping or electric-current heating.

At frequencies œâ>Œìe‚ÄãeùúîsubscriptŒìùëíùëí\omega>\Gamma_{ee} where the hydrodynamic theory fails, the response of the system is better described by more conventional approaches, e.g., the Boltzmann kinetic equation neglecting electron-electron collisions. Among the Dirac materials, graphene has been the most common target of such calculations. Nonlinear conductivity of graphene has been addressed in many theoretical studies.¬†Mikhailov (2007, 2011); Gullans¬†et¬†al. (2013); Cheng¬†et¬†al. (2014); Yao¬†et¬†al. (2014); Cheng¬†et¬†al. (2015); Mikhailov (2016); Tokman¬†et¬†al. (2016); Cheng¬†et¬†al. (2017); Manzoni¬†et¬†al. ; Wang¬†et¬†al. (2016); Rostami¬†et¬†al. (2017); Sun¬†et¬†al. As discussed in our previous work¬†Sun¬†et¬†al. , the differences between the hydrodynamic and kinetic regimes (Fig.¬†2) becomes conspicuous at temperatures TùëáT exceeding the chemical potential Œºùúá\mu, where graphene contains two types of carriers, electrons and thermally excited holes. In the kinetic regime, electrons and holes tend to move in opposite directions when driven by the electric field. Their contributions to the electric current add up. In the hydrodynamic regime, due to frequent interparticle collisions, all the carriers tend to move together. Hence, the electron and hole currents partially cancel. As a consequence, there is an increased effective mass per unit charge, resulting in reduced linear and second-order nonlinear conductivities.Sun¬†et¬†al. In this work we show that the third-order electrodynamic response also exhibits distinct behaviors in the two regimes, in accord with this physical picture.

The remainder of the paper is organized is follows. Section II gives a summary of our main results such as the analytical formula for the third-order nonlinear conductivity of an isotropic Dirac fluid. This formula is simple and universal. It is valid for any mass mùëöm, chemical potential Œºùúá\mu, temperature TùëáT, and space dimension dùëëd if momentum nonconserving processes can be neglected, Œìd‚Üí0‚ÜísubscriptŒìùëë0\Gamma_{d}\to 0. We also discuss the general form of the higher nonlinear conductivities tensors œÉ(n)superscriptùúéùëõ\sigma^{(n)} of odd order nùëõn. In Sec.¬†III we introduce the relativistic hydrodynamic equations and apply them to the massless case, such as graphene. In Sec.¬†IV we give the derivation of œÉ(3)superscriptùúé3\sigma^{(3)}, including the case of an external applied magnetic field. In Sec.¬†V we apply our results for œÉ(3)superscriptùúé3\sigma^{(3)} to computing the third harmonic generation. In Sec.¬†VI we discuss the Kerr effect and its influence on the hydrodynamic collective modes of the fluid. In Sec.¬†VII we compute the magnetic-field-induced third-order circular birefringence. The concluding remarks are given in Sec.¬†VIII. Appendix¬†A provides a summary of the analytical expressions for the thermodynamic quantities of a massless Dirac fluid. Appendix¬†B outlines the derivation of œÉ(3)superscriptùúé3\sigma^{(3)} for a more realistic case of a finite scattering rate ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d}.

III Hydrodynamics

III.1 Hydrodynamic equations

The hydrodynamic equations for an ideal relativistic charged fluid areLandau¬†and¬†Lifshitz (1987)

The thermodynamic quantities, the proper charge density œÅ0=e‚Äãn0subscriptùúå0ùëísubscriptùëõ0\rho_{0}=en_{0}, the enthalpy density WùëäW and the pressure PùëÉP are all defined in the fictitious proper frame moving with the local liquid. Note that n‚â°œÅ/eùëõùúåùëín\equiv\rho/e is defined as the effective charge carrier density and is in general not the same as particle density. For example, in graphene at high temperature, there are both electrons and holes, and nùëõn will be the number of electrons minus the number of holes. We define the hydrodynamic effective mass as m‚àó‚â°W/(n‚Äãv2)superscriptùëö‚àóùëäùëõsuperscriptùë£2m^{\ast}\equiv W/(nv^{2}). And we define

Cise=nW‚Äã(‚àÇW‚àÇn)ise‚àí1=nW‚Äã(‚àÇP‚àÇn)ise=1m‚àó‚Äãv2‚Äã(‚àÇP‚àÇn)isesubscriptùê∂iseùëõùëäsubscriptùëäùëõise1ùëõùëäsubscriptùëÉùëõise1superscriptùëö‚àósuperscriptùë£2subscriptùëÉùëõise\displaystyle C_{\mathrm{ise}}=\frac{n}{W}\left(\frac{\partial W}{\partial n}\right)_{\mathrm{ise}}-1=\frac{n}{W}\left(\frac{\partial P}{\partial n}\right)_{\mathrm{ise}}=\frac{1}{m^{\ast}\!v^{2}}\left(\frac{\partial P}{\partial n}\right)_{\mathrm{ise}} (9)

as the dimensionless bulk isentropic modulus of the electron fluidSun¬†et¬†al. . For example, it has the value 1/d1ùëë1/d for massless Dirac particles in space dimension dùëëd. Out of the three thermodynamic quantities WùëäW, PùëÉP and œÅ0subscriptùúå0\rho_{0} only two are independent. Thus the independent variables are any two thermodynamic quantities and the local flow velocity ùêÆùêÆ\mathbf{u}. This set of equations (6) is closed.

Alternatively, these hydrodynamic equations can be derived from the Boltzmann kinetic equation with the inter particle collision integral but neglecting the many-body interaction correction to the thermodynamic quantities, as shown in Ref.¬†Briskot¬†et¬†al., 2015 and also the covariant version in Appendix C.

where nE=Œ≥2‚ÄãW‚àíPsubscriptùëõùê∏superscriptùõæ2ùëäùëÉn_{E}=\gamma^{2}W-P is the energy density of the electrons (relative to zero doping and temperature case), and nE‚Äã0=W‚àíPsubscriptùëõùê∏0ùëäùëÉn_{E0}=W-P is the same quantity but in the proper frame. Equation¬†(11) is the relativistic version of the Euler equation, Eq.¬†(12) is the conservation of the energy current and Eq.¬†(13) is the conservation of the charge current. Terms due to viscosity and dissipative thermal conductivity are neglected because they affect the conductivities only through O‚Äã(q2)ùëÇsuperscriptùëû2O(q^{2}) terms. To simplify the notations, the asymptotic velocity has been taken to be v=1ùë£1v=1 except for the Lorentz force term due to the magnetic field ùêÅùêÅ\mathbf{B}. Note that the magnetic field is related to the electric one by ‚àá√óùêÑ=‚àíc‚àí1‚Äã‚àÇtùêÅ‚àáùêÑsuperscriptùëê1subscriptùë°ùêÅ\nabla\times\mathbf{E}=-c^{-1}\partial_{t}\mathbf{B}. Since we neglect finite-qùëûq effects in this work, we must set ‚àá√óùêÑ=0‚àáùêÑ0\nabla\times\mathbf{E}=0, so that the magnetic field is considered time-independent.

Starting from Eqs.¬†(11), (12) and (13) we can compute the linear and in principle, any higher-order nonlinear optical conductivities œÉ(N)superscriptùúéùëÅ\sigma^{(N)} by expanding all the dynamic variables in powers of the electric field ùêÑùêÑ\mathbf{E}. This procedure and its results are presented in the following sections.

III.2 Hydrodynamic regime of graphene

Hydrodynamic regime is not a phase of matter but a domain of frequency-momentum diagram [see, e.g., Fig.¬†1 of Ref.¬†Sun¬†et¬†al., ] where the hydrodynamic equations work well as an effective theory. This regime is defined by inequalities Œìd,œâ‚â™Œìe‚Äãemuch-less-thansubscriptŒìùëëùúîsubscriptŒìùëíùëí\Gamma_{d},\,\omega\ll\Gamma_{ee} and q‚â™le‚Äãe‚àí1much-less-thanùëûsuperscriptsubscriptùëôùëíùëí1q\ll l_{ee}^{-1}, which can be satisfied in some pure solid-state systems. The electron-electron collision rate Œìe‚Äãe‚Äã(n,T)subscriptŒìùëíùëíùëõùëá\Gamma_{ee}(n,T) that sets the upper bound on the hydrodynamic regime depends on temperature and doping level of the electron system. For example, in graphene, Œìe‚ÄãesubscriptŒìùëíùëí\Gamma_{ee} scales as ‚àºln‚Å°(2‚ÄãŒº/T)‚Äã(T2/Œº)similar-toabsent2ùúáùëásuperscriptùëá2ùúá\sim\ln(2\mu/T)(T^{2}/\mu) at low TùëáT and as ‚àºŒ±2‚ÄãTsimilar-toabsentsuperscriptùõº2ùëá\sim\alpha^{2}T at T‚â´Œºmuch-greater-thanùëáùúáT\gg\mu with Œ±‚àº1similar-toùõº1\alpha\sim 1. For a rough estimate, we connect these two formulas by a naive interpolation with the relative weights Œº/(T+Œº)ùúáùëáùúá\mu/(T+\mu) and T/(T+ŒºT/(T+\mu), respectively. The corresponding boundary of the hydrodynamic domain (blue region) is shown by the upper dashed line in Fig.¬†2. The other important scattering rate shown in the same Figure is ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d}. For ultra clean graphene encapsulated in hexagonal boron nitride (hBN), the major contribution to ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d} is the electron-phonon scattering Œìp‚ÄãhsubscriptŒìùëù‚Ñé\Gamma_{ph}. The electron-phonon scattering suppresses the hydrodynamic behavior if Œìp‚Äãh>Œìe‚ÄãesubscriptŒìùëù‚ÑésubscriptŒìùëíùëí\Gamma_{ph}>\Gamma_{ee}. However, our theoretical estimation of Œìp‚ÄãhsubscriptŒìùëù‚Ñé\Gamma_{ph} and Œìe‚ÄãesubscriptŒìùëíùëí\Gamma_{ee} indicates that the hydrodynamic regime of graphene is fairly large, as shown in Fig.¬†2. Furthermore, in a nonequlibrum situation where the electron system is at high temperature TùëáT while the lattice temperature TlsubscriptùëáùëôT_{l} remains low, Œìe‚ÄãesubscriptŒìùëíùëí\Gamma_{ee} is enhanced while the Œìp‚Äãh=Œìp‚Äãh‚Äã(Tl,T,n)subscriptŒìùëù‚ÑésubscriptŒìùëù‚Ñésubscriptùëáùëôùëáùëõ\Gamma_{ph}=\Gamma_{ph}(T_{l},T,n) remains small, and so the hydrodynamic window could be wider. Such a nonequlibrum situation can be realized either through optical pumping¬†Ni¬†et¬†al. (2016) or by Joule heating due to an electric current.¬†Son¬†et¬†al. (2018)

Recent experiments¬†Bandurin¬†et¬†al. (2016); Crossno¬†et¬†al. (2016); Krishna Kumar¬†et¬†al. (2017); Moll¬†et¬†al. (2016) explored the dc transport in several pure 2D conductors in the regime Œìd‚â™Œìe‚Äãemuch-less-thansubscriptŒìùëësubscriptŒìùëíùëí\Gamma_{d}\ll\Gamma_{ee}, i.e., near the horizontal axis œâ=0ùúî0\omega=0 of Fig.¬†2. These measurements revealed signatures of viscous electron flow, which manifest themselves through a combination of high viscosity ŒΩ=v2/Œìe‚Äãeùúàsuperscriptùë£2subscriptŒìùëíùëí\nu=v^{2}/\Gamma_{ee} and geometrical restriction on the flow. Because of the particular focus of these studies, the lower viscosity, higher temperature regime was labeled as nonhydrodynamic. From our point of view, viscosity is just one of very many hydrodynamic phenomena rather than its essential element. Actually, in the high-temperature regime, where the electron-hole plasma becomes a more perfect fluid,M√ºller¬†et¬†al. (2009) hydrodynamic effects should be of crucial importance. They are predicted to give dramatically different optical responses compared to the noninteracting kinetic theory.¬†Sun¬†et¬†al.

IV Third-order nonlinear optical conductivity

IV.1 The general charged fluid

Since we neglect the ùí™‚Äã(q2)ùí™superscriptùëû2\mathcal{O}(q^{2}) nonlocal corrections, œÉ(N)superscriptùúéùëÅ\sigma^{(N)} could be derived by simply considering the fluid driven by a uniform electric field. (The dynamic magnetic field ùêÅùêÅ\mathbf{B} is zero in this case.) The hydrodynamic equations¬†(6) simplify to

‚àÇtùê©=œÅ‚ÄãùêÑ,‚àÇtœÅ=0,‚àÇtSn=0.formulae-sequencesubscriptùë°ùê©ùúåùêÑformulae-sequencesubscriptùë°ùúå0subscriptùë°subscriptùëÜùëõ0\displaystyle\partial_{t}\mathbf{p}=\rho\mathbf{E}\,,\quad\partial_{t}\rho=0\,,\quad\partial_{t}S_{n}=0\,. (14)

The last relation in Eq.¬†(14) comes from the fact that the hydrodynamic flow is isentropic. The second relation in Eq.¬†(14) comes from the charge continuity equation. It entails that the charge density œÅùúå\rho stays constant. In turn, the first relation in Eq.¬†(14) implies that ùê©ùê©\mathbf{p} is strictly linear in ùêÑùêÑ\mathbf{E}. IV.3 2D Dirac fluid with a static magnetic field

The uniform hydrodynamic equations with a static magnetic field are

‚àÇtpi=œÅ‚ÄãEi+œÅ‚Äã1c‚Äãœµi‚Äãj‚Äãk‚Äãuj‚ÄãBk,‚àÇtœÅ=0,‚àÇtSn=0.formulae-sequencesubscriptùë°subscriptùëùùëñùúåsubscriptùê∏ùëñùúå1ùëêsubscriptitalic-œµùëñùëóùëòsubscriptùë¢ùëósubscriptùêµùëòformulae-sequencesubscriptùë°ùúå0subscriptùë°subscriptùëÜùëõ0\displaystyle\partial_{t}p_{i}=\rho E_{i}+\rho\frac{1}{c}\epsilon_{ijk}u_{j}B_{k}\,,\quad\partial_{t}\rho=0\,,\quad\partial_{t}S_{n}=0\,. IV.4 Analysis of œÉ(3)superscriptùúé3\sigma^{(3)}

The simple tensorial structure of Eq.¬†(4) is a result of rotational symmetry and local equilibrium nature of an ideal charged fluid. For comparison, in the high frequency kinetic/quantum regime of graphene, the tensorial structure of œÉ(3)superscriptùúé3\sigma^{(3)} is more complicated due to contributions from interband transitions and disorder scattering effects.¬†Cheng¬†et¬†al. (2014, 2015); Mikhailov (2016) In the hydrodynamic regime, the interband transitions are suppressed by fast e-e scattering, resulting in the simple expression of Eq.¬†(4).

The magnitude of hydrodynamic œÉ(3)superscriptùúé3\sigma^{(3)} is also different from that of the kinetic theory. Applied to graphene at T=0ùëá0T=0, our result for Dh(3)superscriptsubscriptùê∑‚Ñé3D_{h}^{(3)} is

Dh(3)‚Äã(T=0)=g48‚ÄãœÄ‚Äãe4‚ÄãvF‚Ñè3‚ÄãkF=2‚ÄãDk(3),superscriptsubscriptùê∑‚Ñé3ùëá0ùëî48ùúãsuperscriptùëí4subscriptùë£ùêπsuperscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi3subscriptùëòùêπ2superscriptsubscriptùê∑ùëò3\displaystyle D_{h}^{(3)}(T=0)=\frac{g}{48\pi}\frac{e^{4}v_{F}}{\hbar^{3}k_{F}}=2D_{k}^{(3)}\,, (33)

which is twice the third-order spectral weight Dk(3)superscriptsubscriptùê∑ùëò3D_{k}^{(3)} from the collisionless Boltzmann transport theory Mikhailov (2016); Cheng¬†et¬†al. (2014); Mikhailov (2007). This difference could be measured by, e.g., third harmonic generation to be discussed in Sec.¬†V.

Comparing the third-order nonlinear response with the usual linear one, we notice that the third-order current is suppressed by the parameter

Œæ=(‚àíe‚ÄãE/œâm‚àó‚Äãv)2‚â™1.ùúâsuperscriptùëíùê∏ùúîsuperscriptùëö‚àóùë£2much-less-than1\displaystyle\xi=\left(\frac{-eE/\omega}{m^{\ast}v}\right)^{2}\ll 1\,. (34)

This factor is different in the nonrelativistic and the ultrarelativistic regimes because m‚àósuperscriptùëöm^{*} depends on the Fermi momentum pFsubscriptùëùùêπp_{F}. As a result, in the nonrelativisitic case parameter Œæùúâ\xi is smaller by the factor of (vF/v)2‚â™1much-less-thansuperscriptsubscriptùë£ùêπùë£21(v_{F}/v)^{2}\ll 1 than the ultrarelativistic case. This factor vanishes for a system with the parabolic dispersion, which corresponds to v‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùë£v\to\infty. Indeed, for such a system all nonlinearities at zero qùëûq should be absent because of the Galilean invariance (Kohn‚Äôs theorem). On the other hand, in graphene at zero temperature, which is an example of the ultrarelativistic system, m‚àó‚Äãv=pFsuperscriptùëö‚àóùë£subscriptùëùùêπm^{\ast}v=p_{F}, so that Œæ=(Œ¥‚Äãp/pF)2ùúâsuperscriptùõøùëùsubscriptùëùùêπ2\xi=({\delta p}/{p_{F}})^{2}. Here Œ¥‚Äãp=‚àíe‚ÄãE/œâùõøùëùùëíùê∏ùúî\delta p=-eE/\omega has the physical meaning of the amplitude of electron momentum oscillation caused by the electric field.

The third-order conductivity (4) diverges at the zero frequency limit, which is unphysical. In reality, the divergence is curbed by the momentum relaxation rate ŒìdsubscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{d}, similar to the first order conductivity. A simple but crude way to include the effect of the momentum relaxation is to change all the frequencies œâasubscriptùúîùëé\omega_{a} to œâa+=œâa+i‚ÄãŒìdsuperscriptsubscriptùúîùëésubscriptùúîùëéùëñsubscriptŒìùëë\omega_{a}^{+}=\omega_{a}+i\Gamma_{d}. However, this approach neglects the increase of entropy density due to momentum relaxation. Thus, special care needs to be taken to compute the true nonlinear dc response, as shown in Appendix B.

V Third harmonic generation

One quantity we can derive from œÉ(3)superscriptùúé3\sigma^{(3)} [Eq.¬†(4)] is the third harmonic generation (THG) Mikhailov (2016); Giorgianni¬†et¬†al. (2016). Assume the ac electric field of the incident light is in the xùë•x-direction

ùêÑ‚Äã(t)=x^‚ÄãE‚Äã(œâ)‚Äãe‚àíi‚Äãœâ‚Äãt+c.c.formulae-sequenceùêÑùë°^ùë•ùê∏ùúîsuperscriptùëíùëñùúîùë°cc\mathbf{E}(t)=\hat{x}E(\omega)e^{-i\omega t}+\mathrm{c.c.} (35)

The current, which determines the observable THG signal is

ùê£(3)‚Äã(t)=x^‚ÄãœÉx‚Äãx‚Äãx‚Äãx(3)‚Äã(œâ,œâ,œâ)‚ÄãE‚Äã(œâ)3‚Äãe‚àíi‚Äã3‚Äãœâ‚Äãt+c.c.formulae-sequencesuperscriptùê£3ùë°^ùë•subscriptsuperscriptùúé3ùë•ùë•ùë•ùë•ùúîùúîùúîùê∏superscriptùúî3superscriptùëíùëñ3ùúîùë°cc\mathbf{j}^{(3)}(t)=\hat{x}\sigma^{(3)}_{xxxx}(\omega,\omega,\omega)E(\omega)^{3}e^{-i3\omega t}+\mathrm{c.c.} (36)

Therefore, œÉx‚Äãx‚Äãx‚Äãx(3)‚Äã(œâ,œâ,œâ)subscriptsuperscriptùúé3ùë•ùë•ùë•ùë•ùúîùúîùúî\sigma^{(3)}_{xxxx}(\omega,\omega,\omega) represents the magnitude of the THG. This quantity is plotted in Fig.¬†3 as a function of TùëáT. Also shown in Fig.¬†3 is the prediction of the conventional theory based on random-phase approximation (RPA),¬†Cheng¬†et¬†al. (2015); Mikhailov (2016) which is valid in the kinetic regime. The two curves exhibit different behavior. At zero temperature, the hydrodynamic theory predicts the THG signal which is twice that of the kinetic theory. However, since Œìe‚Äãe=0subscriptŒìùëíùëí0\Gamma_{ee}=0 at T=0ùëá0T=0, the electron system much be in the kinetic regime (Fig.¬†2), and so the actual œÉx‚Äãx‚Äãx‚Äãx(3)‚Äã(œâ,œâ,œâ)subscriptsuperscriptùúé3ùë•ùë•ùë•ùë•ùúîùúîùúî\sigma^{(3)}_{xxxx}(\omega,\omega,\omega) should be close to the kinetic theory value, as sketched by the dashed line. As temperature increases, Œìe‚Äãe=0subscriptŒìùëíùëí0\Gamma_{ee}=0 grows, and the system will experience a crossover from the kinetic to hydrodynamic regime at certain T‚àósuperscriptùëá‚àóT^{\ast}. This crossover temperature is determined by Œìe‚Äãe‚Äã(n,T‚àó)=œâsubscriptŒìùëíùëíùëõsuperscriptùëá‚àóùúî\Gamma_{ee}(n,T^{\ast})=\omega. As temperature increases further, the hydrodynamic third-order optical weight drops as Dh(3)‚àù(m‚àó)‚àí3‚àùT‚àí9proportional-tosubscriptsuperscriptùê∑3‚Ñésuperscriptsuperscriptùëö‚àó3proportional-tosuperscriptùëá9D^{(3)}_{h}\propto(m^{\ast})^{-3}\propto T^{-9} due to the thermal enhancement of the hydrodynamic effective mass m‚àó‚Äã(n,T)superscriptùëö‚àóùëõùëám^{\ast}(n,T). Therefore, the THG drops much faster than what the conventional kinetic theory would predict.

VI The Kerr effect and the demons

The Kerr effect refers to the change of the effective permittivity of a medium due to the third-order nonlinearityLandau¬†and¬†Lifshitz (1984); Boyd (2008). For a 2D charged Dirac fluid, this effect is more conveniently described as the shift of the effective conductivity. One manifestation of the Kerr effect is the renormalization of the frequency of the collective modes in a strong optical field. In the kinetic regimes these modes are the familiar plasmons.¬†Mikhailov (2017); Giorgianni¬†et¬†al. (2016) In the hydrodynamic regime, they are the demons.¬†Sun¬†et¬†al. (2016, )

In general, to describe the collective modes, we need to study response at a finite qùëûq. For small enough qùëûq, we can approximate the result using q=0ùëû0q=0 quantities, as follows. The charge density fluctuation could be represented by means of the Fourier amplitude œÅœâ,qsubscriptùúåùúîùëû\rho_{\omega,q}:

œÅùúå\displaystyle\rho =œÅœâ,q‚Äãei‚Äã(ùê™‚ãÖùê´‚àíœâ‚Äãt)+c.c.absentsubscriptùúåùúîùëûsuperscriptùëíùëñ‚ãÖùê™ùê´ùúîùë°c.c.\displaystyle=\rho_{\omega,q}e^{i(\mathbf{q}\cdot\mathbf{r}-\omega t)}+\text{c.c.} (37)

Assume qùëûq is in the x^^ùë•\hat{x} direction. The corresponding Fourier amplitude of the electric field is Ex=(‚àíi‚Äãq)‚Äãvq‚ÄãœÅœâ,qsubscriptùê∏ùë•ùëñùëûsubscriptùë£ùëûsubscriptùúåùúîùëûE_{x}=(-iq)v_{q}\rho_{\omega,q}, where vqsubscriptùë£ùëûv_{q} is the Coulomb potential. In 2D, it is given by vq=2‚ÄãœÄ/Œ∫‚Äãqsubscriptùë£ùëû2ùúãùúÖùëûv_{q}=2\pi/\kappa q. The electric field induces the current

jx‚Äã(œâ)subscriptùëóùë•ùúî\displaystyle j_{x}(\omega) =œÉ‚Äã(œâ)‚ÄãEx+3‚ÄãœÉx‚Äãx‚Äãx‚Äãx(3)‚Äã(œâ,œâ,‚àíœâ)‚ÄãEx‚ÄãEx‚ÄãEx‚àó.absentùúéùúîsubscriptùê∏ùë•3subscriptsuperscriptùúé3ùë•ùë•ùë•ùë•ùúîùúîùúîsubscriptùê∏ùë•subscriptùê∏ùë•superscriptsubscriptùê∏ùë•‚àó\displaystyle=\sigma(\omega)E_{x}+3\sigma^{(3)}_{xxxx}(\omega,\omega,-\omega)E_{x}E_{x}E_{x}^{\ast}\,. (38)

Using the charge continuity equation ‚àÇtœÅ+‚àáùê£=0subscriptùë°ùúå‚àáùê£0\partial_{t}\rho+\nabla\mathbf{j}=0, we obtain

‚àíi‚Äãœâ‚ÄãœÅ+q2‚Äãvq‚ÄãœÉ‚Äã(œâ)‚ÄãœÅ+3‚Äãq4‚Äãvq3‚ÄãœÉx‚Äãx‚Äãx‚Äãx(3)‚Äã(œâ,œâ,‚àíœâ)‚ÄãœÅ‚ÄãœÅ‚ÄãœÅ‚àó=0.ùëñùúîùúåsuperscriptùëû2subscriptùë£ùëûùúéùúîùúå3superscriptùëû4superscriptsubscriptùë£ùëû3subscriptsuperscriptùúé3ùë•ùë•ùë•ùë•ùúîùúîùúîùúåùúåsuperscriptùúå‚àó0\displaystyle-i\omega\rho+q^{2}v_{q}\sigma(\omega)\rho+3q^{4}v_{q}^{3}\sigma^{(3)}_{xxxx}(\omega,\omega,-\omega)\rho\rho\rho^{\ast}=0\,. (39)

The weak-field dispersion can be obtained from this equation by dropping the last term. When this term is retained, the dispersion acquires the frequency shift proportional to œÉ(3)superscriptùúé3\sigma^{(3)}:

Œ¥‚Äãœâùõøùúî\displaystyle\delta\omega =‚àí3‚Äãi2‚Äãq4‚Äãvq3‚ÄãœÉx‚Äãx‚Äãx‚Äãx(3)‚Äã(œâ,œâ,‚àíœâ)‚Äã|œÅœâ,q|2absent3ùëñ2superscriptùëû4superscriptsubscriptùë£ùëû3subscriptsuperscriptùúé3ùë•ùë•ùë•ùë•ùúîùúîùúîsuperscriptsubscriptùúåùúîùëû2\displaystyle=-\frac{3i}{2}q^{4}v_{q}^{3}\sigma^{(3)}_{xxxx}(\omega,\omega,-\omega)|\rho_{\omega,q}|^{2}
=‚àí3‚Äãi2‚Äãq2‚Äãvq‚ÄãœÉx‚Äãx‚Äãx‚Äãx(3)‚Äã(œâ,œâ,‚àíœâ)‚Äã|Eœâ,q|2.absent3ùëñ2superscriptùëû2subscriptùë£ùëûsubscriptsuperscriptùúé3ùë•ùë•ùë•ùë•ùúîùúîùúîsuperscriptsubscriptùê∏ùúîùëû2\displaystyle=-\frac{3i}{2}q^{2}v_{q}\sigma^{(3)}_{xxxx}(\omega,\omega,-\omega)|E_{\omega,q}|^{2}\,. (40)

[To obtain this relation we also assumed that the linear conductivity has the Drude form œÉ‚Äã(œâ)‚àùœâ‚àí1proportional-toùúéùúîsuperscriptùúî1\sigma(\omega)\propto\omega^{-1}.] Applied to Eq.¬†(4), we obtain the fractional shift of the frequency of the demon:

Œ¥‚Äãœâœâ=‚àí92‚Äãq2‚Äãvq‚ÄãDh(3)œâ4‚Äã|Eœâ,q|2=‚àí34‚Äã(1‚àíCise)‚ÄãŒæ,ùõøùúîùúî92superscriptùëû2subscriptùë£ùëûsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑3‚Ñésuperscriptùúî4superscriptsubscriptùê∏ùúîùëû2341subscriptùê∂iseùúâ\displaystyle\frac{\delta\omega}{\omega}=-\frac{9}{2}q^{2}v_{q}\frac{D^{(3)}_{h}}{\omega^{4}}|E_{\omega,q}|^{2}=-\frac{3}{4}(1-C_{\mathrm{ise}})\xi\,, (41)

where Œæùúâ\xi is defined by Eq.¬†(34). The negative sign of the shift means the collective mode is softened by the strong field. The reason for this is that the third-order conductivity is opposite in sign compared to the linear one, which is due to the current ùê£ùê£\mathbf{j} being a concave function of the momentum density ùê©ùê©\mathbf{p} in a Dirac fluid. The results for the original and shifted demon dispersion in graphene is illustrated by Fig.¬†4. It is remarkable that an appreciable shift occurs already at a relatively low field of E=104‚ÄãV/cmùê∏superscript104VcmE=10^{4}\,\mathrm{V/cm}.

VII Third order circular birefringence

In the presence of an applied magnetic field, there is a finite second term ‚àùœâcproportional-toabsentsubscriptùúîùëê\propto\omega_{c} in Eq.¬†(32), which causes the third-order circular birefringence. As in Sec.¬†IV.3, let us consider a 2D system subject to a normally incident monochromatic light of frequency œâùúî\omega with the electric field polarized in the xùë•x-direction. The generated third-order current has frequency œâs=3‚Äãœâsubscriptùúîùë†3ùúî\omega_{s}=3\omega and has a nonzero yùë¶y-component

jx‚Äã(3‚Äãœâ)subscriptùëóùë•3ùúî\displaystyle j_{x}(3\omega) =œÉx‚Äãx‚Äãx‚Äãx(3)‚ÄãEx3‚Äã(œâ)=i‚ÄãDh(3)‚Äã3œâ3,absentsubscriptsuperscriptùúé3ùë•ùë•ùë•ùë•subscriptsuperscriptùê∏3ùë•ùúîùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑‚Ñé33superscriptùúî3\displaystyle=\sigma^{(3)}_{xxxx}E^{3}_{x}(\omega)=iD_{h}^{(3)}\frac{3}{\omega^{3}}\,,
jy‚Äã(3‚Äãœâ)subscriptùëóùë¶3ùúî\displaystyle j_{y}(3\omega) =œÉy‚Äãx‚Äãx‚Äãx(3)‚ÄãEx3‚Äã(œâ)=i‚ÄãDh(3)‚Äã3œâ3‚Äã(4‚Äãi‚Äãœâc3‚Äãœâ).absentsubscriptsuperscriptùúé3ùë¶ùë•ùë•ùë•subscriptsuperscriptùê∏3ùë•ùúîùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑‚Ñé33superscriptùúî34ùëñsubscriptùúîùëê3ùúî\displaystyle=\sigma^{(3)}_{yxxx}E^{3}_{x}(\omega)=iD_{h}^{(3)}\frac{3}{\omega^{3}}\left(\frac{4i\omega_{c}}{3\omega}\right)\,. (42)

In the dissipationless limit, œâùúî\omega is real, and jysubscriptùëóùë¶j_{y} has a œÄ/2ùúã2\pi/2 phase difference relative to jxsubscriptùëóùë•j_{x}. Therefore, the third harmonic light will be elliptically polarized with the principal axis along xùë•x. Its ellipticity, conventionally denoted by tan‚Å°Œ∏ùúÉ\tan\theta, is given by

tan‚Å°Œ∏=|jyjx|=43‚Äãœâcœâ.ùúÉsubscriptùëóùë¶subscriptùëóùë•43subscriptùúîùëêùúî\displaystyle\tan\theta=\left|\frac{j_{y}}{j_{x}}\right|=\frac{4}{3}\frac{\omega_{c}}{\omega}\,. (43)

Therefore, the ellipticity scales as œâc=e‚ÄãB/m‚àó‚Äãcsubscriptùúîùëêùëíùêµsuperscriptùëö‚àóùëê\omega_{c}=eB/m^{\ast}c, which decays with temperature if the carrier density nùëõn is fixed. This is illustrated by Fig.¬†5 for the case of graphene. From Eq.¬†(26), there is also circular birefringence in the linear response, with tan‚Å°Œ∏=œâc/œâùúÉsubscriptùúîùëêùúî\tan\theta=\omega_{c}/\omega, which differs only by the constant numerical factor 4/3434/3. It is also plotted in Fig.¬†5, for an easy comparison.

VIII Discussion

We showed that the third-order nonlinear conductivity œÉ(3)superscriptùúé3\sigma^{(3)} of a Dirac fluid has a universal functional form for any mass, chemical potential, temperature, and space dimension. It is remarkable that the third-order and the linear conductivities are simply related through Eqs.¬†(5) and (31). Although we have used graphene as an example in the numerical calculations, our formulas, e.g., Eqs.¬†(4) and (5), hold for any Lorentz-invariant Dirac fluid. As such, these formulas should be a good approximation to surface states of topological insulators and Dirac/Weyl semimetals, provided they are in the hydrodynamic regime. We also studied the field-induced renormalization of the dispersion of the collective modes (demons) and the third-order circular birefringence in the presence of a static magnetic field.

In the future it would be interesting to investigate hydrodynamics of non-Dirac fluids, that is, systems without the Lorentz symmetry. This will be important for more realistic modeling of ultrapure solid-state systems where hydrodynamic regime has been reported (GaAs, graphene, and PdCoO2subscriptPdCoO2\mathrm{PdCoO_{2}}). In the above systems, although the quasi particle band dispersion is approximately Dirac-like, the Coulomb interaction tends to break this quasi Lorentz symmetry because it propagates with the speed of light cùëêc rather than vùë£v. It would also be interesting to study nonlinear thermal transport in the Dirac fluid. The case of phonon fluids has been studied half a century agoNielsen¬†and¬†Shklovskii (1969).

(54)

After the standard symmetrization procedure, Eq.¬†(54) renders œÉ(3)superscriptùúé3\sigma^{(3)} with dissipation. The cooling rate ŒìEsubscriptŒìùê∏\Gamma_{E} could arise due to electron-phonon coupling and is crucial for eliminating the divergence of œÉ(3)superscriptùúé3\sigma^{(3)} in the dc limit. In this dc limit, due to work done by the electric field, the electron-hole fluid would be heated up by order E2/ŒìEsuperscriptùê∏2subscriptŒìùê∏E^{2}/\Gamma_{E}, thus inducing a large correction to the current at the third order. This is a physical reason why setting ŒìE‚Üí0‚ÜísubscriptŒìùê∏0\Gamma_{E}\to 0 would lead to a diverging œÉ(3)superscriptùúé3\sigma^{(3)}.

In the dissipationless limit, Eq.¬†(54) becomes Eq.¬†(23). Moreover, it can be readily checked that if ŒìE+2‚ÄãŒìk=2‚ÄãŒìdsubscriptŒìùê∏2subscriptŒìùëò2subscriptŒìùëë\Gamma_{E}+2\Gamma_{k}=2\Gamma_{d}, Eq.¬†(54) becomes identical to Eq.¬†(23) as well. Under this condition, the fluid dynamics becomes isentropic again: the kinetic energy is lost to the environment due to momentum relaxation instead of converted into heat of the fluid.

Appendix C Relativistic Boltzmann equation

The relativistic Boltzmann equation is

(PŒº‚Äã‚àÇŒº+FŒº‚ÄãŒΩ‚ÄãPŒº‚Äã‚àÇPŒΩ)‚ÄãfR‚Äã(X,P)=I‚Äã[fR],superscriptùëÉùúásubscriptùúásubscriptùêπùúáùúàsuperscriptùëÉùúásubscriptsubscriptùëÉùúàsubscriptùëìùëÖùëãùëÉùêºdelimited-[]subscriptùëìùëÖ\displaystyle\left(P^{\mu}\partial_{\mu}+F_{\mu\nu}P^{\mu}\partial_{P_{\nu}}\right)f_{R}(X,P)=I[f_{R}]\,, (55)

where fR‚Äã(X,P)subscriptùëìùëÖùëãùëÉf_{R}(X,P) is the relativistic distribution function and I‚Äã[fR]ùêºdelimited-[]subscriptùëìùëÖI[f_{R}] is the collision integral due to interactions. Note that the space-time coordinate XŒºsuperscriptùëãùúáX^{\mu} and the momentum PŒº=m‚ÄãuŒºsuperscriptùëÉùúáùëösuperscriptùë¢ùúáP^{\mu}=mu^{\mu} are covariant ones. For a given XŒºsuperscriptùëãùúáX^{\mu}, the distribution function fR‚Äã(X,P)subscriptùëìùëÖùëãùëÉf_{R}(X,P) can be defined as the density of world lines whose local tangent is PŒºsuperscriptùëÉùúáP^{\mu}. Mathematically, fR‚Äã(X,P)subscriptùëìùëÖùëãùëÉf_{R}(X,P) is a scalar function defined on the tangent bundle of the d+1ùëë1d+1 dimensional space-time. If we focus on one species of particle with a fixed mass mùëöm, then fR‚Äã(X,P)subscriptùëìùëÖùëãùëÉf_{R}(X,P) is related to the ordinary distribution function through

fR‚Äã(X,P)=f‚Äã(t,ùê´,ùê©)‚ÄãŒ¥‚Äã(E2‚àíp2‚àím2).subscriptùëìùëÖùëãùëÉùëìùë°ùê´ùê©ùõøsuperscriptùê∏2superscriptùëù2superscriptùëö2\displaystyle f_{R}(X,P)=f(t,\mathbf{r},\mathbf{p})\delta(E^{2}-p^{2}-m^{2})\,. (56)

We integrate Eq.¬†(55) over PùëÉP to get the charge continuity equation:

‚àÇŒºJŒº=0,subscriptùúásuperscriptùêΩùúá0\displaystyle\partial_{\mu}J^{\mu}=0\,,
jŒº=‚à´ùëëP‚ÄãPŒº‚ÄãfR‚Äã(X,P)=‚à´ùëëùê©‚Äã(1,ùêØ)‚Äãf‚Äã(t,ùê´,ùê©),superscriptùëóùúádifferential-dùëÉsuperscriptùëÉùúásubscriptùëìùëÖùëãùëÉdifferential-dùê©1ùêØùëìùë°ùê´ùê©\displaystyle j^{\mu}=\int dPP^{\mu}f_{R}(X,P)=\int d\mathbf{p}\;(1,\mathbf{v})f(t,\mathbf{r},\mathbf{p})\,, (57)

which is the second equation in Eq.¬†(6).

Next, we multiply Eq.¬†(55) by PŒ±superscriptùëÉùõºP^{\alpha} and again integrate it over PùëÉP. We get the continuity equation for the energy-momentum tensor,

‚àÇŒºTŒº‚ÄãŒΩ=FŒºŒΩ‚ÄãJŒº,subscriptùúásuperscriptùëáùúáùúàsuperscriptsubscriptùêπùúáùúàsuperscriptùêΩùúá\displaystyle\partial_{\mu}T^{\mu\nu}=F_{\mu}^{\nu}J^{\mu}\,,
TŒº‚ÄãŒΩ=‚à´ùëëP‚ÄãPŒº‚ÄãPŒΩ‚ÄãfR‚Äã(X,P)=‚à´ùëëùê©‚ÄãPŒº‚ÄãPŒΩ‚Äã1E‚Äãf‚Äã(t,ùê´,ùê©),superscriptùëáùúáùúàdifferential-dùëÉsuperscriptùëÉùúásuperscriptùëÉùúàsubscriptùëìùëÖùëãùëÉdifferential-dùê©superscriptùëÉùúásuperscriptùëÉùúà1ùê∏ùëìùë°ùê´ùê©\displaystyle T^{\mu\nu}=\int dPP^{\mu}P^{\nu}f_{R}(X,P)=\int d\mathbf{p}\;P^{\mu}P^{\nu}\frac{1}{E}f(t,\mathbf{r},\mathbf{p})\,, (58)

which is the first equation in Eq.¬†(6).
